item.title: GoogleAppEngine and Mobile Phones
item.description: GoogleAppEngine makes it easy to create CGI style webapps that can use many of Google's tools and api's. These webapps can be formatted for cellphone web browsers as a cross platform cell phone application. Combined with Google Gears for offline use, this is an interesting option for cell phone apps.

item.title: Happy New Year, Pythonistas!
item.description: PyCon 2007 podcast series is up and running!

item.title: Python on Mac OS X 10.5 Leopard
item.description: Mac OS X 10.5, Leopard has upgraded Python support including PyObjC 2.0 and other goodies.

item.title: The Future of Programming
item.description: The future of programming will be a Python based Toolkit/IDE including a drag and drop GUI Form-Creator using extended HTML and CSS standards, facilitating cooperative server side and client side code execution, and allowing for automatic right-sizing of the user interface.

item.title: Web 3.0 and Nanoprogramming
item.description: Web 3.0 consists of Web 2.0 programs for mobile devices, and Nanoprogramming is programming for nanocomputers (embedded and mobile devices) and there is a revolution afoot, the times are a-changin'. Will Python lead the way or fall back?

item.title: SimPy
item.description: This podcast is an interview with Dr. Klaus Muller in Amsterdam and Professor Tony Vignaux in New Zealand about their creation, SimPY, an object-oriented, process-based discrete-event simulation language based on standard Python.

item.title: More Mobile Musings
item.description: More about programming for mobile devices, the discussion in the blogosphere about concurrency and Python3000, etc.

item.title: Smartphones, PDA's and iPod's
item.description: Continuing to explore Python on mobile devices, iPhone, iPod Touch, gPhone, Zaurus, Jython, and PyMite, are discussed.

item.title: Python for Mobile Interfaces
item.description: Python for Mobile Interfaces is a clarion call for Pythonistas to pioneer the future of alternative user interfaces for mobile phones, PDA's, and wearable computers, including voice recognition, gesture recognition, and wearable computing.

item.title: from __future__ import *
item.description: Python 3.0, Python magazine, Resolver, Vernor Vinge's "Rainbow's End", the future of programming languages, my two family computer scientists-to-be, and other Python related topics.

item.title: Exciting Times
item.description: Exciting times in my life as I start my sales company in Frequency Control Products, creating the website using Pythonic tools the Maker and Firedrop. Also, I now have 2 children who are going to be Computer Scientists, and upcoming attractions.

item.title: My Dinner Conversation with Bill Rodman and Chris Merle at PyCon 2007
item.description: A jovial and wide ranging dinner conversation recorded at PyCon 2007, with Bill Rodman, Chris Merle, and myself. Topics include Python, other programming languages, Gaelic, Science Fiction, podcasting and audio books.

item.title: pre-EuroPython Special Edition
item.description: A request for volunteers to help David Boddie and myself to provide audio coverage of EuroPython in Vilnius, Lithuania July 9-11. Also a few other matters.

item.title: Python411 Returns
item.description: After a brief hiatus, Python411 returns with coverage of Silverlight, Firedrop. the Maker CMS, Codex, Python 3000, Brainbench, Expert Rating, and other topics.

item.title: How Python Runs
item.description: A guest podcast by Chris Hefele who explores in detail the various Python implementations including CPython, Jython, IronPython, Shedskin, Psycho, Stackless, Parrot, and PyPy. Enjoy!

item.title: An Interview with Michael Moran
item.description: An interview with Michael Moran who's new Django application Codex combines the functionality of a blog and a wiki. After talking about Codex, Django, and Python we go really far afield and talk about Google Code, Eclipse, PyDev, Pyjamas and all things code related!

item.title: An Interview with Scott Sheffield
item.description: An Interview with Scott Sheffield

item.title: Python Advocacy
item.description: A talk about Python Advocacy given by Jeff Rush, along with the question and answer session, recorded at PyCon 2007 in Dallas, Texas.

item.title: An Interview with Wesley Chun
item.description: An interview with Wesley Chun, author of Core Python Programming, recorded at PyCon 2007 in Dallas, Texas.

item.title: PyCon 2007 Reflections: the PodCast
item.description: Reflections on PyCon 2007, including olpc, Advocacy, Education, Crunchy, jobs, IPython, Tosca Widgets, people, community and more.

item.title: An Interview with Gerald Spreer
item.description: This is an interview with Gerald Spreer, lead developer of "the Maker" an open source web content management system. Gerald and I talked last June and the project has come a long way since then and it is fascinating to hear what he has learned along the way.

item.title: An Interview with Jeff Rush
item.description: This is an interview with Jeff Rush, Co-Chair of PyCon 2007 in Dallas Texas, active in the Dallas area Python users group and a leader of Python advocacy activities, discussing the building excitement for PyCon and some of the new and interesting plans for this year's conference.

item.title: State of the Python Union
item.description: This is a mini pre-PyCon 2007 State of the Python Union address, including Python 3000, Pycon 2007, the 6 different implementations, and the Standard Library.

item.title: Persistent Storage using Pickle and Shelve
item.description: A brief introduction to persistent storage using the standard library modules pickle and shelve

item.title: PyCon 2007 Earlybird Preview
item.description: I just registered for PyCon 2007 in Dallas February 23-25 and here is a preview of the talks I most want to attend.

item.title: The Python Papers
item.description: An interview with Tennessee Leeuwenburg of the Python Papers, a new online technical journal with great promise!

item.title: PyCon 2007
item.description: The talks and tutorials and keynote addresses for PyCon 2007 (in Dallas Feb 23-25, 2007) have just been announced. It should be the best PyCon yet. Also, more feedback on Python for Cell Phones.

item.title: Quick Update
item.description: Just a quick update before I go on a business trip; some useful feedback from listeners following my podcasts about Python for cell phones; running IronPython on my Motorola Q cell phone (Windows Mobile System 5.0); get ready now for PyCon 2007 in February in Dallas; and a call for Pythonistas to interview.

item.title: Python for Cell Phones
item.description: Since I needed a new cell phone, I decided to look into the various options for running Python on cell phones, and in this podcast I share the results of my investigation.

item.title: Core Python
item.description: Core Python 2'nd Edition covers Python 2.5 and is quite possibly the best Python book ever written. This podcast delves a little into Chapter 11, "Functions and Functional Programming", including inner functions, closures, decorators, generators and coroutines.

item.title: GUI Programming with Tkinter: Part II
item.description: A tutorial lecture on GUI programming with Tkinter by Dr. Sergio Rey of San Diego State University. Part II.

item.title: GUI Programming with Tkinter: Part I
item.description: A tutorial lecture on GUI programming with Tkinter by Dr. Sergio Rey of San Diego State University. Part I.

item.title: An Interview with Michael Moran
item.description: An interview with Michael Moran about his work creating a web portal using web frameworks with databases.

item.title: WxPython in Action
item.description: An interview with authors Robin Dunn and Noel Rappin

item.title: An Introduction to Threading with Python
item.description: An introduction to Threading with Python by Chris Hefele is a guest podcast in the Python411 podcast series.

item.title: Agile Testing with Python
item.description: Agile Testing with the Python Test Frameworks was presented at PyCon 2005 by Grig Gheorghiu. Although audio files of the 2006 talks are not up yet, there are many good audio files of some of the talks at PyCon 2005 located at http://us.pycon.org/talks.

item.title: Game Programming with PyGame
item.description: An interview with Andy Harris, professor of Computer Science at Indiana-Purdue University in Indianapolis, Indiana and author of several books about computer programming. Andy is working on a new book about Game Programming using PyGame. More information about the book, and a link to his game MailPilot as well as source code and notes can be found at http://www.cs.iupui.edu/~aharris/pgl/python411/

item.title: Milestones
item.description: Upcoming Python Milestones include the release of Python 2.5 and the first production release of IronPython. There is a new version of the Maker. Guido chooses Django, sort of. Duncan MacNeil illustrates how he solved his Windows printing problems with a short Python script.

item.title: Modules
item.description: A lecture by Dr. Sergio Rey of San Diego State University about Python Modules and docstrings.

item.title: Python and Flash
item.description: An interview with Sam Feltus, the creator of Sonoma Sunshine, a module to interface Python with Flash, for coding web animations and 3D effects. Also an errata by Dr. Sergio Rey concerning and earlier podcast about Numpy.

item.title: PythonCard
item.description: A podcast about PythonCard, a very easy to learn and use framework for creating GUI's, built on top of wxPython. The podcast features an introduction by Ron Stephens followed by the audio from a presentation by Kevin Altis that was originally given at PyCon 2005.

item.title: Data Structures
item.description: A lecture by Dr. Sergio Rey of San Diego St. University on Python Data Sturctures, including strings, lists, tuples, dictionaries and sets.

item.title: Python Community News
item.description: Python community news from EuroPython including Guido's talk about Python 3000, Alan Kay's talk, the $100 laptop project, new tutorials on threads and concurrent programming, robotics and lingusitics. Comments on the new book WxPython in Action and more.

item.title: Top Ten Future Show Topics
item.description: The top ten pythonic subjects I would like to interview someone about or host a guest podcast about are discussed on this show.

item.title: Object Orientation
item.description: A lecture by Professor Serge Rey of San Diego State University about object oriented programming in the field of Geographical Sciences and Mapping. At 1.5 hours in length, the first half is about object oriented principles and concepts in general, the second half is about applying these principles using the Python programming language.

item.title: An Interview with Gerald Spreer, creator of "the Maker"
item.description: An interview with Gerald Spreer, creator of the Maker, an open source content management system for web sites.

item.title: The Joy of Hacking
item.description: A lecture by Dr. Sergio Rey of San Diego State University on numeric programming with Python.

item.title: Numeric Programming with Python
item.description: A lecture by Dr. Sergio Rey of San Diego State University on numeric programming with Python.

item.title: Python News and Views
item.description: wxPython, SPE IDE, and a new user group in Montreal, Canada

item.title: wxPython
item.description: wxPython is a cross platform, open source GUI toolkit.

item.title: An RPG Game in One Week!
item.description: An RPG game created in only one week by Jay Barnson, hear the story by guest podcaster Ryan Lunar.

item.title: Network Programming Libraries
item.description: socket, socketserver, ftp, urllib, httplib, cgilib and more.

item.title: An Interview with Mike Muller, founder of the Python Academy in Leipzig, Germany
item.description: An Interview with Mike Muller, founder of the Python Academy in Leipzig, Germany

item.title: Mash-Up
item.description: A Python411 mash-up of topics including Python 3000.

item.title: An Interview with Michael Foord, aka "Fuzzyman"
item.description: A Python411 interview with Michael Foord, aka Fuzzyman, Python hacker who has contributed a disproportionate amount and quality of open source projects, applications, tools, tutorials, Pyzine articles, and more in his mere 3 years in the community.

item.title: PyGame
item.description: PyGame

item.title: Python News
item.description: Python News

item.title: The Spread Module
item.description: The Spread Module

item.title: PyCon 2006 Report
item.description: A Report on PyCon 2006 in Dallas, Texas.

item.title: Pre PyCon Podcast
item.description: A Preview of PyCon 2006 in Dallas, Texas.

item.title: Computer Science
item.description: Python is prefect for learning about Computer Science, including object oriented programmming, polymorphism, inheritance, and encapsulation, as well as algorithms that are exponentially difficult, nlogn algortihms, intractable problems, and Turing's halting problem.

item.title: I'm Going to Pycon!!!
item.description: Well, I'm going to PyCon2006 in Dallas, Texas afterall, along with my beautiful wife and my 16 year old son who willalso be an attendee at the sessions. I heartily recomment that others investigate and sign up to go, the Tutorials will be held on Thursday and the main event on Friday, Saturday and Sunday February 24,25, and 26.

item.title: Dictionaries
item.description: Dictionaries

item.title: PyCon 2006
item.description: PyCon2006

item.title: Ask Merlin
item.description: Ask Merlin is a Python script or program of my own. First, written as a procedural, command line program, it evolved to a functional program, and then to a class based, object oriented program, and then to a GUI based and ultimately a CGI based online script. Its evolution gives a good pedagogical opportunity to discusss classes and object oriented programming.

item.title: More Magic
item.description: More Magic is about Decorators, Generators, Generator Expressions, Exceptions, and Magic Methods.

item.title: Pragmatic Python
item.description: Pragmatic Python, Python Standard Library, Pickle, the Python Challenge, Komodo, WingIDE, and Bruce, the Presentation Tool.

item.title: Python and XML
item.description: Python and XML, HTML and AJAX

item.title: Python3000
item.description: Python3000 is the somewhat mythical future version of Python and this podcast explores the evolutionary development of Python, past, present and future.

item.title: PyGoogle
item.description: PyGoogle is a python module for easy and powerful access to the Google API.

item.title: Magic
item.description: Magic is a Python411 podcast about List Comprehensions, Iterators, Generators, Generator Expressions, Decorators and Sets.

item.title: TurboGears
item.description: TurboGears, pyGoogle, Beautiful Soup, Firedrop, and other web programming and feedback from listeners

item.title: Scripting
item.description: Scripting, CGI, random module, Ask Merlin, I Ching, Eliza, new books and Blogarithms.

item.title: Miscellaneous
item.description: TurboGears MegaFrameWork for web programming, Komodo IDE, pyChing and pyNewWings, and hints about future podcasts.

item.title: Jython
item.description: Jython is the felicitous union of Python and Java, a version of Python written in pure Java that runs on the Java Virtual Machine and gives access to the Java class libraries, as well as the ability to compile Jython code into .class files using the jythonc compiler

item.title: Python's Niche
item.description: Python's niche may well be as the best general purpose progamming language

item.title: Top 10 Python Web Sites Awards
item.description: AwareTek's Top 10 Python Web Sites Awards

item.title: Modules, Packages, and Disutils
item.description: Modules, Packages, and Disutils

item.title: Language Comparisons
item.description: Comparing Python to Ruby, Perl, Java, C#, VB.Net, C, C++, JavaScript, PHP etc.

item.title: CGI Programming with Python
item.description: CGI programming using Python covers basic CGI programming with Python using the cgi module and cgi.FieldStorage(), as well as teh HTMl form and table tags needed.

item.title: Firedrop2
item.description: Firedrop2 is a weblogging and content management system written in Python by Hans Nowak and supplemented by Fuzzyman with a plugin system. Open source and extensible in Python, Firedrop2 is good tool and a worthwhile learning exercise.

item.title: Books and Tutorials
item.description: This podcast is about Tutorials and Books for learning Python.

item.title: Python for Mobile Devices Podcast
item.description: This podcast is about Python for Mobile Devices, including the Apple iPod, Nokia Series 60 phone, Sharp Zaurus, iRiver mp3 player, Palm devices, Pocket PC devices and more.

item.title: GUI Toolkits for Python
item.description: This podcast is about GUI toolkits for Python

item.title: Computer Programming for Everybody
item.description: This podcast is about Computer Programming for Everybody

item.title: python411 Introduction to Python
item.description: python411 is a series of podcasts about the programming language Python. This podcast is an introduction to the series
